docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- The Carter Administration is holding up sales of police weapons to Argentina, Uruguay, El Salvador and other countries because the weapons could be used to suppress human rights, the State Department said today.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- The Carter Administration is holding up sales of police weapons to Argentina, Uruguay, El Salvador and other countries because the weapons could be used to suppress human rights, the State Department said today.

headline.main: Police-Gear Sales to Latins Held Up

docs.snippet: The United States is gradually but finally getting out of the business of providing weapons and know-how to the police agencies of authoritarian governments. Withdrawal from these once-thriving programs has reached a point where it is crimping the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States is gradually but finally getting out of the business of providing weapons and know-how to the police agencies of authoritarian governments. Withdrawal from these once-thriving programs has reached a point where it is crimping the sales of American manufacturers of small arms and other police paraphernalia, cut their interests should not override the nation's on the course now set by Congress and the Executive.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 31 There has been a significant interruption in the pattern of trade and payments liberalization that characterized world economic policy of the last three decades, the International Monetary Fund warned today.

docs.snippet: Let me begin with a confession. I am a news addict. Upon awakening I flip on the Today show to learn what events transpired during the night. On the commuter train which takes me to work, I scour The New York Times, and find myself absorbed in tales...
docs.lead_paragraph: Let me begin with a confession. I am a news addict. Upon awakening I flip on the Today show to learn what events transpired during the night. On the commuter train which takes me to work, I scour The New York Times, and find myself absorbed in tales of earthquakes, diplomacy and economics. I read the newspaper as religiously as my grandparents read their prayerbooks. The sacramental character of the news extends into the evening.
docs.abstract: Reprint of article by Prof Stanley Milgram, which appeared in Antioch Rev, on meaning of news and why it occupies place of special significance for so many; drawing (L)

docs.snippet: BERKELEY, Calif. President Carter has gone to great lengths to persuade us of his "undeviating commitment" to the advancement of human rights abroad. Clearly, there is much to applaud in his forthright stand, but there are also same significant...
docs.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. President Carter has gone to great lengths to persuade us of his "undeviating commitment" to the advancement of human rights abroad. Clearly, there is much to applaud in his forthright stand, but there are also same significant inconsistencies in his approach to this critical issue.

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15 Terence A. Todman, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today that everyone he talked with during a two-day official visit to Argentina said "violations of human rights have decreased."

docs.abstract: US Asst Sec Todman says talks with Argentine officials appear to indicate that human rights violations have decreased; meets with Pres Videla, Buenos Aires (S)
